description:
Costa Rica, 17.03.2020-13.04.2020
National suspension of lessons as a preventive and necessary measure in the efforts to contain the spread of COVID-19, complementary provisions

Article 1: Lessons in the Costa Rican education system are temporarily suspended for the levels of Preschool Education, 1, 2 and 3 of General Basic Education (EGB) and Diversified Education in all public and private educational modalities authorized or recognized by the Ministry of Public Education, throughout the country.

Article 2: The national suspension of lessons agreed by the authorities of health and public education will be in force from tuesday march 17 to friday april 3, 2020. The re-entry to lessons of the student population of public and private schools and teachers, administrative teachers and technical teachers of public and private schools will take place on Monday April 13 this year.

Costa Rica, March 25, 2020 
Decree N° 42256-MGP-S:
Starting March 25 at 23:59 hours, foreign persons with legal stay under the migratory categories “Permanent Residence,” “Temporary Residence,” “Special Categories,” or “Non-Residents” in subcategory “Stay” are discouraged from leaving the country, and if they do so will not be allowed entry into Costa Rica. This does not apply to foreign persons that drive international means of transportation. This applies for air, sea, and land travel. [From Article 2 and 5]
Those in the categories above who enter Costa Rica in an unauthorized fashion will have their legal stay in the country canceled. [From Article 6]

description:
Costa Rica, 28.02.2020:
The authorities of the Ministry of Health, Costa Rican Social Security Fund (CCSS), Civil Aviation, General Directorate of Migration and Aliens, Costa Rican Red Cross and Aeris publish the Juan Santamaría airport protocol against COVID-19.

The pilot is supposed to land the aircraft so that it is received in the special rooms, where the person with symptoms exits for the respective analysis by the paramedics.

If the patient presents symptoms that may give rise to a  suspicion of carrying the virus, the San Rafael de Alajuela Hospital is notified for boarding and isolation, while each of the remaining passengers is interviewed in order to follow them up by levels of risks, following the protocol of Health Surveillance.

Under the slogan ""Con vos podemos"", the official campaign was launched to receive financial donations in order to bring humanitarian aid to vulnerable people and families affected by the emergency caused by Covid-19.

The Board of Directors of the Central Bank of Costa Rica (BCCR), in a session held on Monday, April 13, 2020, empowered its Administration to acquire, in the secondary market, holdings from the Ministry of Finance in colones for a maximum amount of ₡ 250,000 million.

The acquisition in the secondary market by the Central Bank of titles of the Ministry of Finance does not constitute financing to the Government, since the purchase of the holdings would be made to a third party, who would be the one who receives the money for the acquisition made by the Central Bank.

Given that this instrument is an exceptional mechanism, the Central Bank restricts its participation to situations of systemic tension, and therefore limits the amount of its intervention and imposes restrictions on the type of holdings that can be acquired and their issue and placement date.

The Central Bank will publish on its website the information on the secondary market transactions carried out under this agreement, at the end of each day in which it carries out said transactions.

These are PINN innovation and technology transfer projects to support the health emergency, with an investment of up to ₵ 712 million.

The maximum amount to be awarded per project will be ₵ 142,000,000 and the maximum execution period will be 12 months.

Meanwhile, the Incentive Fund will open a call for an amount of up to ₵ 79 million on May 15 to support research on issues related to COVID-19.

3. Promotion of capacity development in small and medium-sized enterprises to better cope with the economic consequences of COVID-19.

description:
Costa Rica, 23.03.2020:
The Central Administration is instructed and the Decentralized Administration is urged to establish a basic operating service plan, to guarantee the continuity of the essential tasks in order to ensure the institutional public purpose. For these purposes, institutions may require a maximum attendance of 20% of their total payroll.
The basic operating service plan must include:
a) The application of the teleworking modality in those positions that are possible.
b) The justification of the services that are essential for the operation of the institution.
c) Strict health measures to be applied in the case of workers who must attend in person.

The institutions of the Central Administration must:
a) Apply the telework modality in everything since it is teleworkable.
b) Grant vacations to all those servants who have
accumulated vacation periods.
c) If the servants do not have accumulated periods,
vacation advancement is authorized.

All public servants who are over 65 years of age or have risk factors must be guaranteed with an option to work remotely or take vacation.

Decree N° 42253-MOPT-S
Costa Rica is putting in place a nocturnal obligatory vehicle restriction in order to mitigate the effects of COVID-19. Between 22:00 and 05:00 hours, no vehicular transit is allowed all the national territory. [from Articles 2, 3]
